page.lettertext:
fol.16r
stil Ro
m
[to my]
L Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. because I would not that the talk
w
ch
I have had w
th
Mons
r
Biland
should be longe unknowen
unto yo
r
L. if my former letter of
e 2 of this p
nt
should
happ
e
to miscary, I thought best to prevent it by sending
an oth
r
coppy. The 20 enseignes of footemen w
ch
were
appointed from hence to
e siege of
Rouen
are growen so feeble
& full of infirmity, by reason of theyr long continewance in
e
shippes, whereto they have bin forced for want of a winde, that
now they are admitted to refreshe themselves w
th
in
e townes:
but in places neer adjoyning, to the end they may be redy when
the winde draweth easterly. The time of theyr returne is
limited to
e 15 day of m
r
che after theyr account, but if
neede require I think they shalbe spared for one moneth longer,
The
states of Holland
have resolved to levy for theyr owne
extraordinary quote for the next sommers service, 6 enseignes
of footemen & 3 cornet
of horse, but what is ment to be
don by the reason of
e Provinces, wee are not yet adv
r
tised,
They do make full account to bring into the field at
e least
10000 foote & 2500 horse w
th
40 peeces of Battery.
W
ch
no dout will suffice to annoy
e ennemy many waies
both by getting places of spetiall importance, & by deriving
some strength from his army in
France,
But howsoever it be,
to crave yo
r
L. pardon if I speake w
th
out jugem
t
in these
martiall affaires, there might an other course be taken to
e ennemies greater detriment: if either of them selves or
by her
Ma
ties
suasion they can be wonne to yeeld unto it,
for seing in mans discourse, they can enjoy but a while
the benefit of theyr former or future victories, if God shall
not prosper theyr actions of France, & for asmuch as
e
King
is w
th
out any power to
s
ve a foote, being like by that
meanes to be greatly distressed, I cannot possibly
und
r
stand how
e want of
e King can be bett
r
supplied & the
good of the Provinces more effectually procured, then if they
would determine to make a defensive warre for
e next sommers
fol.16v
season & to send some 5 or 6000 of theyr souldiers
into
France, of w
ch
theyr might conveniently be raised
towards
2000 Englishe including
e 7 companies w
ch
are alredy
there in
s
vice, & the rest to be taken of theyr owne entertainment. For
undoutedly these Provinces are so apparantly well ass
ured
as consydering the extraordinary band
w
ch
they purpose
to
erect, unless that
Parma
should returne w
th
all his
strength
owt of France, they may easily forbeare the foresaid
number
& hold theyr owne here at home w
th
e rest of theyr forces.
Besides a publick benefit wherof they
w
th
others
above others
shall be
greatest
takers, they shall also be eased of those
excessive
charg
of a campe,
t
consist in
vision of vitt
ails,
powder, shott, carriages & shipping, w
th
the intertai
nment of
many officers, & oth
r
tinent expenses, that
amount in the
field to very great sommes: If her Ma
ty
be
willing
that
e King be thus assisted, theare is a great
opportunitie
to
swade
e States unto it where theyr forces
now embarked
shalbe safely there arrived. For if as then it
will please
her Hig
nes
& the King to be earnest in requesting [that]
those that are gon for France alredy, may be [there continued
& that as many more may be added as may
s
ve to
the
accomplishing of
e foresaid nomber, w
th
a furder
declaration
that for as many as may be spared of
e English
companion
her Ma
ty
is resolved
t
they shalbe there employed
as long
as this necessity of the Kinge doth require it, I
should
hardly conceave
t
they would use theruppon any g
reat
contradiction. Of all that I dout
will be
opposit unto it
Count Maurice
is the chiefest, for
that I
knowe he is desyrous to do somewhat
here himself
for the encrease of his credyt. And
then the
States of
Friseland
will dislike it utterly, for that
they think
assuredly to recover this sommer the towne of
Steenwick
Howbeit for that it will
fit th
e
but [little, to get ether]
that or any oth
r
towne, if the King be o
verthrowen
